title: Rock crystal gem-set fluted cup and cover

  title_text: Rock crystal gem-set fluted cup and cover

  preference: main

 North

  styles_periods_indexing_terms: Mughal

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: gold (metal) diamond (mineral) enamel paint quartz crystal

  techniques_name: painting (image making) carving (processes)

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is an eight-lobed cup and cover. It is carved and inlaid with crystals
 decorated with gold wire and enamel paint. The exterior is decorated with floral motifs and scrolling leaves
 with some diamonds embedded within the motif design.

  subject_terms_1: flower (motif) foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Drinking cups Diamond jewelry
 Mogul Empire

  subject_terms_3: Indian decorative arts

  sgcool_label_text: The carved rock crystal eight-lobed cup and cover is inlaid with precious stones within a system of gold wire. This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India there was a great revival in the art of rock crystal carving
 and Mughal craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers
 plants
 scrolling vines and animal forms allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.

metadata.title_text: Rock crystal gem-set fluted cup and cover
metadata.materials_name: gold (metal) diamond (mineral) enamel paint quartz crystal
metadata.physical_appearance: This is an eight-lobed cup and cover. It is carved and inlaid with crystals, decorated with gold wire and enamel paint. The exterior is decorated with floral motifs and scrolling leaves, with some diamonds embedded within the motif design.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Drinking cups Diamond jewelry, Mogul Empire
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The carved rock crystal eight-lobed cup and cover is inlaid with precious stones within a system of gold wire. This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India there was a great revival in the art of rock crystal carving, and Mughal craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers, plants, scrolling vines and animal forms allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.
